security_audit.summary: Pure prompt-based skill containing only instructional content and educational frameworks. No executable code, no network access, no file system access beyond reading reference documents. Contains only persona definitions, reasoning questions, principles, and research references.

content.value_statement: Skills often lack measurable proficiency levels. This skill applies CEFR, Bloom's Taxonomy, and DigComp frameworks to map any skill to internationally recognized levels with validated progression and coherent skill progression tracks.
actual_capabilities: Map any skill to CEFR proficiency levels (A1-C2) with measurable indicators
Apply Bloom's Taxonomy cognitive levels to assessment design
Validate skill progressions for coherence (no regression, no missing prerequisites)
Design proficiency-matched assessments at each level
Align learning objectives with international frameworks
Detect and correct intuitive leveling errors
limitations: Does not provide external assessment or certification
Requires human judgment for complex skill boundaries
Reference files contain framework knowledge but are not executable
Proficiency claims are for guidance, not formal credentials

use_cases.title: Design coherent skill progressions
use_cases.description: Map course skills to CEFR/Bloom's frameworks ensuring no regression and proper prerequisite ordering across chapters.

use_cases.title: Create level-matched assessments
use_cases.description: Design assessments that match cognitive complexity to proficiency level using action verbs and assessment types from Bloom's Taxonomy.

use_cases.title: Validate skill coherence
use_cases.description: Check skills for uniqueness, proper naming, progressive leveling, prerequisite satisfaction, and connectivity to progression tracks.

prompt_templates.title: Basic skill mapping
prompt_templates.scenario: Map a single skill to proficiency levels
prompt_templates.prompt: Map the skill of [SKILL NAME] to CEFR proficiency levels (A1-C2). For each level, provide: what the student can do, measurable indicators, and appropriate assessment types from Bloom's Taxonomy.

prompt_templates.title: Coherence validation
prompt_templates.prompt: Run the 5 coherence validation tests (Uniqueness, Naming, Progression, Prerequisites, Connectivity) on these skills: [SKILL LIST]. Identify any issues and suggest corrections.

prompt_templates.title: Assessment design
prompt_templates.prompt: Design assessments for [SKILL] at [CEFR LEVEL]. Include: appropriate Bloom's cognitive level, action verbs, assessment type, example questions, and time allocation.

prompt_templates.title: Framework alignment
prompt_templates.scenario: Align complex skills to multiple frameworks
prompt_templates.prompt: Map [COMPLEX SKILL] to CEFR, Bloom's Taxonomy, and DigComp frameworks simultaneously. Show how the frameworks complement each other for this skill and provide integrated proficiency descriptors.

output_examples.input: Map 'Python decorators' to CEFR proficiency levels
output: A1: Student can identify what a decorator is and recognize decorator syntax
A2: Student can apply existing decorators to classes using documentation
B1: Student can implement decorators from specification to solve problems
B2: Student can analyze decorator patterns and evaluate when to use them
C1: Student can create novel decorator patterns and teach others effectively

best_practices: Start with measurable indicators rather than intuitive level assignments
Validate progressions for non-regression (A1â†’A2â†’B1, never A2â†’A1)

anti_patterns: Assigning levels based on intuition without measurable indicators
Teaching B1 content without A1-A2 foundation (broken progression)
Using only Remember-level assessments for higher proficiency claims
Allowing skill fragmentation across chapters without deepening

faq.question: What frameworks does this skill use?
faq.answer: CEFR (6 proficiency levels), Bloom's Taxonomy (6 cognitive levels), DigComp (digital competence), and Cognitive Load Theory.

faq.question: How many proficiency levels are defined?
faq.answer: Six levels: A1 (Breakthrough), A2 (Elementary), B1 (Threshold), B2 (Vantage), C1 (Effective Operational), C2 (Mastery).

faq.question: How does this integrate with other skills?
faq.answer: Works with learning-objectives, concept-scaffolding, assessment-builder, and book-scaffolding skills for complete curriculum design.

faq.question: Is the output suitable for formal credentials?
faq.answer: Framework mappings provide guidance aligned with internationally recognized standards but do not replace formal certification.

faq.question: What are the 5 coherence validation tests?
faq.answer: Uniqueness (canonical names), Progression (non-decreasing levels), Prerequisites (foundations taught first), Connectivity (skill deepens across lessons), Naming (consistent terminology).

faq.question: How does this differ from simple difficulty labels?
faq.answer: Uses research-validated frameworks with measurable indicators, not subjective labels. Levels correlate with cognitive demand and empirically-validated learning progressions.
